comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content:
Dear Flickr viewers, 

The reason people don't smile in early photographs is because they had to stay perfectly still for long exposure times, and in the studio, their neck was held by an uncomfortable clamp.

Also in this case, life on the goldfields was hard and often short
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 37395183@N02
comment._content: Auch wenn dieses Paar nicht sehr glücklich aussieht, so kann man sich gut vorstellen, dass sie wesentlich länger bei einem Shooting gesessen sind, als in unserer digitalisierten Zeit. Dennoch ein sehr stimmungsvolles Bild, das viel über die damalige Zeit aussagt. Sehr schön.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I wonder whether this might be the theatre manager Charles Poole (1815-1871) with his actor/director wife, who were connected with the Prince of Wales Theatre, Sydney during the late 1850s and early 1860s (at various points they also worked in Tasmania and Melbourne). If you are familiar with the Sydney newspapers of the late 1850s and early 1860s these are perhaps the first people you'd think of when you come across a mid 19th century reference to 'Mr and Mrs Poole'. If you search the digitised newspapers you can see just how prominent they were during this period. Per a brief obit item which appeared in the Argus on 21 February, 1872, p.5 (column d), Charles Poole died at Boston, in the US, in December 1871 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-page231886 . Per this item, Poole and his wife appear to have moved to the US in the later 1860s. If this were theatre manager Charles Poole and his actor/director wife, I suspect that the pic might have in fact been taken in the early to mid 1860s. Quite a bit of speculation here though!!! PS - It's interesting that this pic should appear in a sequence of theatre pics. Is that just a co-incidence?

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content:
Hi quasymody,
The Holtermann collection is a document of ordinary working people on the goldfields of central New South Wales in the first half of the 1870's. Whoever this couple was they were not Charles Poole and his wife. She is probably pregnant so they are only young. They are in their best clothes but you can see from the shabbiness and his rough boots that he is probably a miner or shopowner in those goldfields boom towns like Hill End or Gulgong. Charles Poole would have been about 58 when this photogrpah was taken.
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Yes, I was speculating quite a bit!
